title: Business News:  Michaels Agrees  To Go Private in  Deal With Apollo  ----  By Allison Prang
text:
Michaels Cos. is going private in a leveraged buyout by Apollo Global Management Inc. that values the arts-and-crafts seller at $3.3 billion, after the pandemic boosted the retailer's fortunes.

Business at Michaels suffered early in the Covid-19 pandemic when many of its 1,200 locations were temporarily closed. But sales surged in the summer and fall after many homebound people spent more time -- and money -- on crafting, knitting and decorating their homes.

This would be the second time the retailer is run by a private-equity owner. Michaels was taken private in 2006 by Bain Capital and Blackstone Group LP in a deal valued at more than $6 billion. It went public again in 2014.

Michaels Chairman James Quella said Wednesday that the company's board "firmly believes Apollo's offer represents a compelling value to our shareholders."

Apollo, which has more than $450 billion in assets, is offering to buy Michaels shares for $22 apiece. The companies said the offer is a 47% premium to where shares closed Feb. 26, the day before speculation about a deal surfaced. Shares Wednesday rose 22% to $22.02.

Apollo and Michaels said the deal agreement allows for a 25-day go-shop period where Michaels can look at other options, but there is no assurance that process will lead to a better offer.

Former Walmart Inc. executive Ashley Buchanan became CEO of Michaels in April 2020. In a recent interview with The Wall Street Journal, Mr. Buchanan described the company's old approach as being more focused on seasonal home decor. "We've transitioned to being arts-and-crafts driven," he said in the interview.

Crafts sales have been strong during the pandemic as consumers have sheltered in place. In the retailer's fiscal third quarter ended Oct. 31, net sales climbed around 15% and comparable-store sales -- a key metric for growth in the retail business -- rose about 16%.

Before the health crisis, Michaels was grappling with drooping sales. It reported $5.07 billion in net sales for its fiscal year ended Feb. 1, 2020, down from the prior year, which also recorded a decline. Results for its just-ended fiscal year are due out Thursday.
